original_data.question:
A 62-year-old patient has been hospitalized for a week due to a stroke. One week into the hospitalization, he develops a fever and purulent cough. His vitals include: heart rate 88/min, respiratory rate 20/min, temperature 38.4°C (101.1°F), and blood pressure 110/85 mm Hg. On physical examination, he has basal crackles on the right side of the chest. Chest radiography shows a new consolidation on the same side. Complete blood count is as follows:
Hemoglobin 16 mg/dL
Hematocrit 50%
Leukocyte count 8,900/mm3
Neutrophils 72%
Bands 4%
Eosinophils 2%
Basophils 0%
Lymphocytes 17%
Monocytes 5%
Platelet count 280,000/mm3
What is the most likely causal microorganism?

model_response:
The patient has a new infiltrate and an elevated white blood cell count with a predominance of neutrophils. This suggests a bacterial infection. The most common bacterial infections in the post-stroke period are aspiration pneumonia and infections related to decubitus ulcers. The most common organisms are anaerobes. However, this patient has a new infiltrate, which suggests a more virulent organism. The most likely causal microorganism is Streptococcus pneumoniae.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Any period of seven consecutive days.

A group of pathological conditions characterized by sudden, non-convulsive loss of neurological function due to BRAIN ISCHEMIA or INTRACRANIAL HEMORRHAGES. Stroke is classified by the type of tissue NECROSIS, such as the anatomic location, vasculature involved, etiology, age of the affected individual, and hemorrhagic vs. non-hemorrhagic nature. (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, pp777-810)
Any period of seven consecutive days.
The confinement of a patient in a hospital.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.
The number of times the HEART VENTRICLES contract per unit of time, usually per minute.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
An x-ray examination of the chest.
A chest X-ray finding indicating the presence of a radio-opaque area in the lung. The opacification is caused by fluid or solid material within the airways or lung parenchyma.
A line segment forming part of the perimeter of a plane figure.
The determination of the number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets in a biospecimen.

The volume of packed RED BLOOD CELLS in a blood specimen. The volume is measured by centrifugation in a tube with graduated markings, or with automated blood cell counters. It is an indicator of erythrocyte status in disease. For example, ANEMIA shows a low value; POLYCYTHEMIA, a high value.
Granular leukocytes having a nucleus with three to five lobes connected by slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing fine inconspicuous granules and stainable by neutral dyes.

White blood cells formed in the body's lymphoid tissue. The nucleus is round or ovoid with coarse, irregularly clumped chromatin while the cytoplasm is typically pale blue with azurophilic (if any) granules. Most lymphocytes can be classified as either T or B (with subpopulations of each), or NATURAL KILLER CELLS.

Large, phagocytic mononuclear leukocytes produced in the vertebrate BONE MARROW and released into the BLOOD; contain a large, oval or somewhat indented nucleus surrounded by voluminous cytoplasm and numerous organelles.
A microscopic organism. The term microorganism may refer to a prokaryote or eukaryote, and may be a unicellular or multicellular organism. All taxonomic kingdoms contain microorganisms.
